content: The Act is titled the "Notification of Origin of Telecommunications and Internet Consumer Exchanges Act of 2010" or the "NOTICE Act of 2010". It includes definitions. The Act, titled the "Notification of Origin of Telecommunications and Internet Consumer Exchanges Act of 2010" or the "NOTICE Act of 2010", defines key terms such as business entity, commerce, and consumer. A business entity is any organization established to make a profit by conducting commerce in the United States. Commerce is defined as per the Consumer Product Safety Act, and a consumer is an individual within the U.S. jurisdiction. The Act, titled the "Notification of Origin of Telecommunications and Internet Consumer Exchanges Act of 2010" or the "NOTICE Act of 2010", defines key terms such as business entity, commerce, and consumer. Commerce is defined as per the Consumer Product Safety Act, and a consumer is an individual within the U.S. jurisdiction who purchases goods or services for personal use. The curr_chunk discusses the definition of "customer service communication" as any communication between a consumer and a business entity in commerce. It also defines "telecommunication" as the transmission of information between specified points. The curr_chunk defines "service communication" as telecommunication or wire communication between a consumer and a business entity in commerce. Telecommunication refers to the transmission of chosen information without alteration, while wire communication involves transmitting writing, signs, signals, pictures, and sounds. The curr_chunk defines "wire communication" as the transmission of writing, signs, signals, pictures, and sounds by wire or cable without changing the form or content of the information. Business entities engaged in customer service communications must disclose their physical location as required by SEC. 3. Business entities must disclose their physical location at the beginning of customer service communications, except if all employees or agents are located in the United States. Exceptions to the requirement for business entities to disclose their physical location at the start of customer service communications include situations where all employees or agents are based in the United States or when a consumer knowingly contacts a foreign entity. Communication initiated by consumer to foreign entity exempt from disclosure requirements if the consumer knows the employee is located outside the United States. Communication initiated by consumer to foreign entity exempt from disclosure requirements if the employee is located outside the United States. Exclusions apply for emergency services and business entities as defined by the Federal Trade Commission. Emergency services are exempt from disclosure requirements, as defined by the Federal Trade Commission. The Commission may exclude certain business entities or customer service communications if exceptionally compelling circumstances justify it. Each business entity must meet a certification requirement annually. The Commission may exclude certain business entities or customer service communications from disclosure requirements if exceptionally compelling circumstances justify it. Each business entity participating in customer service communication must certify annually to the Federal Trade Commission. The Commission will promulgate necessary regulations within one year of the enactment of this Act. The Federal Trade Commission requires business entities involved in customer service communication to certify compliance with disclosure requirements. The Commission will establish regulations within one year of the Act's enactment, and the requirements will apply to communications one year after the Act's enactment date. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. Any failure to comply with section 3 is considered a violation of a regulation under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Federal Trade Commission has the power to prevent violations of this Act and its regulations in the same manner as the Federal Trade Commission Act. Any person violating this Act or its regulations will be subject to penalties under the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Federal Trade Commission has the authority to enforce this Act in the same manner as its own regulations. Any person violating regulations under this Act will face penalties as per the Federal Trade Commission Act. The authority of the Federal Trade Commission is not limited by this Act.
